Package org.neo4j.kernel.impl.index.schema

Class BlockStorage<KEY,​VALUE>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.neo4j.kernel.impl.index.schema.BlockStorage<KEY,​VALUE>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Closeable, AutoCloseable
    class BlockStorage<KEY,​VALUE>
extends Object
implements Closeable
    Transforms an unordered stream of key-value pairs (BlockEntry) to an ordered one. It does so in two phases: 1. ADD: Entries are added through #add(KEY, VALUE). Those entries are buffered in memory until there are enough of them to fill up a Block. At that point they are sorted and flushed out to a file. This file will eventually contain multiple Blocks that each contain many entries in sorted order. When there are no more entries to add doneAdding() is called and the last Block is flushed to file. 2. MERGE: By calling merge(int, Cancellation) (after doneAdding() has been called) the multiple Blocks are merge joined into a new file resulting in larger blocks of sorted entries. Those larger blocks are then merge joined back to the original file. Merging continues in this ping pong fashion until there is only a single large block in the resulting file. The entries are now ready to be read in sorted order, call reader().

      • merge

        public void merge​(int mergeFactor,
                  BlockStorage.Cancellation cancellation)
           throws IOException
        There are two files: sourceFile and targetFile. Blocks are merged, mergeFactor at the time, from source to target. When all blocks from source have been merged into a larger block one merge iteration is done and source and target are flipped. As long as source contain more than a single block more merge iterations are needed and we start over again. When source only contain a single block we are finished and the extra file is deleted and blockFile contains the result with a single sorted block. See performSingleMerge(int, BlockReader, StoreChannel, Cancellation, ScopedBuffer[], ByteBuffer) for further details.
        Parameters:
        mergeFactor - See performSingleMerge(int, BlockReader, StoreChannel, Cancellation, ScopedBuffer[], ByteBuffer).
        cancellation - Injected so that this merge can be cancelled, if an external request to do that comes in. A cancelled merge will leave the same end state file/channel-wise, just not quite completed, which is fine because the merge was cancelled meaning that the result will not be used for anything other than deletion.
        Throws:
        IOException - If something goes wrong when reading from file.

      • calculateNumberOfEntriesWrittenDuringMerges

        static long calculateNumberOfEntriesWrittenDuringMerges​(long entryCount,
                                                        long numberOfBlocks,
                                                        int mergeFactor)
        Calculates number of entries that will be written, given an entry count, number of blocks and a merge factor. During merge entries are merged and written, potentially multiple times depending on number of blocks and merge factor.
        Parameters:
        entryCount - number of entries to merge.
        numberOfBlocks - number of blocks that these entries exist in.
        mergeFactor - the merge factor to use when merging.
        Returns:
        number of entries written in total when merging these entries, which exists in the given number of blocks, merged with the given merge factor.

      • performSingleMerge

        private int performSingleMerge​(int mergeFactor,
                               BlockReader<KEY,​VALUE> reader,
                               StoreChannel targetChannel,
                               BlockStorage.Cancellation cancellation,
                               ScopedBuffer[] readBuffers,
                               ByteBuffer writeBuffer)
                        throws IOException
        Merge some number of blocks, how many is decided by mergeFactor, into a single sorted block. This is done by opening BlockEntryReader on each block that we want to merge and give them to a MergingBlockEntryReader. The BlockEntryReaders are pulled from a BlockReader that iterate over Blocks in file in sequential order. MergingBlockEntryReader pull head from each BlockEntryReader and hand them out in sorted order, making the multiple entry readers look like a single large and sorted entry reader. The large block resulting from the merge is written down to targetChannel by calling writeBlock(StoreChannel, BlockEntryCursor, long, long, Cancellation, IntConsumer, ByteBuffer).
        Parameters:
        mergeFactor - How many blocks to merge at the same time. Influence how much memory will be used because each merge block will have it's own ByteBuffer that they read from.
        reader - The BlockReader to pull blocks / BlockEntryReaders from.
        targetChannel - The StoreChannel to write the merge result to. Result will be appended to current position.
        cancellation - Injected so that this merge can be cancelled, if an external request to do that comes in.
        readBuffers - buffers for all block readers.
        writeBuffer - buffer for writing merged blocks.
        Returns:
        The number of blocks that where merged, most often this will be equal to mergeFactor but can be less if there are fewer blocks left in source.
        Throws:
        IOException - If something goes wrong when reading from file.
